title: @Meddler: Is Ashe's new "Can't crit, but gets bonus damage from crit chance" a test?

embed.description: Another old timer within League's ever-deepening champion pool, Ashe has seen almost six years shoot by with her launch kit largely intact. Until now! We're not rebuilding her from the ground up, but we have made some pretty meaningful changes to her abilities all intended to solidify Ashe as League's premier utility carry.

body:
Ashe's kit is getting a SERIOUS change in that she can't critically strike anymore, but still gains bonus damage from crit chance and crit damage modifiers. This sounds like you're testing this first on Ashe so that you might phase out "crit chance" entirely in favor of a non-RNG system on EVERY Champion.

Am I on the right track, or am I jumping at shadows?

replies.body:
We do not have any plans at present to remove Crit or change how it fundamentally works for the game as a whole.

Giving different champions different ways of interacting with it as a stat is something we're interested in exploring further though. That might mean things like a champion who creates a shield for themselves when they crit instead of dealing extra damage, individual champions like Ashe that give up crits entirely for other bonuses, champions with extra crit chance and a CD on how often they personally can crit etc.
Sounds interesting. Any thoughts on CCing an enemy with a crit (with an Udyr-like delay between CC's on the same target)? Or maybe magic damage crits?
There's a crossbow in a game called Pillars of Eternity that does this. If you crit you deal 30% less crit damage but the enemy is hobbled (=snared) for a few seconds.

The issue with your math is that your 200 and 400 damage only takes normal crit into account, so what you're measuring is the difference between someone who can crit, and someone who cannot crit under the normal crit rules. What it doesn't take into consideration is that Ashe doesn't crit, but **she still does consistent bonus damage based on crit chance**

With your math, a champ deals 200 damage without a crit, 400 with it. Let's say they deal this damage at 50% chance. Let's also assume, for the ease of math, that they are attacking at 1.0 attack speed, or 1 attack per second. Using math, we can determine that over 4 attacks you will deal **AN AVERAGE OF** 2 critical hits and 2 non-critical hits, totalling 400 + 400 + 200 + 200 = 1200 total damage over 4 hits **ON AVERAGE**. 

Now, let's say Ashe deals the exact same base damage, but is using her new critical hit system: with 50% crit chance, **Ashe will deal a bonus consistent 50% damage.** This means that instead of dealing 200 base damage without crits, or 400 damage with one by chance, she will instead deal 300 damage consistently (200 + 100[50% of 200] = 300). This means that over the course of 4 attacks, Ashe is ALWAYS dealing 1200 damage (300 x 4). Rather than an average, it is a constant. 

The difference here is that Ashe will ALWAYS and consistently deal 1200 damage over those 4 hits, whereas in the current crit system, 4 hits could yield anywhere between 800 damage (with 0 crits landed) or 1600 damage (all hits land critically). It's about the difference between dealing damage consistently or dealing damage randomly. The idea is that, over time, the amounts balance due to how CHANCE works over consistent damage, and how math dictates that averages will occur.

If we had 100 AD, 10% bonus damage, and 10 attacks, we would do 110 damage per attack, which would be 1,100 damage after 10 attacks. Do you see how this is exactly the same damage that we got when we had 10% crit chance? **The only dps difference between bonus damage and crit, literally the only difference, is that bonus damage can't vary with RNG. Otherwise, they produce exactly the same damage.**

So, now that we have established that bonus damage gives exactly the same damage that we expect from crit. We would change items so that crit chance would be completely. Infinity Edge would replace its crit strike chance with a % AA amp, for example.

It's called a "crit chance rework" because while it removes crit chance, it serves as the direct replacement.
